TypeSignature.Value: .class public interface auto ansi abstract IScrollInfo

Docs.summary: Represents the main scrollable region inside a control.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Primitives.IScrollInfo> interface exposes access to methods that enable logical scrolling of child content as well as computing which child elements are visible. In addition, it defines properties used to define the scrollable region.
Logical scrolling enables scrolling to the next element in the logical tree. Physical scrolling, in contrast, scrolls content by a defined measurable increment in a specified direction. If you require physical scrolling instead of logical scrolling, wrap the host <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Panel> element in a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ScrollViewer> and set the value of its <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ScrollViewer.CanContentScroll%2A> property to `false`.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property bool CanHorizontallyScroll { bool get(); void set(bool value); };

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether scrolling on the horizontal axis is possible.
Docs.value: if scrolling is possible; otherwise, . This property has no default value.

remarks.format:

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property ExtentHeight As Double
public: property double ExtentHeight { double get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets the vertical size of the extent.
Docs.value:
A that represents, in device independent pixels, the vertical size of the extent.
This property has no default value.

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property ExtentWidth As Double
public: property double ExtentWidth { double get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets the horizontal size of the extent.
Docs.value: A that represents, in device independent pixels, the horizontal size of the extent. This property has no default value.

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property HorizontalOffset As Double
public: property double HorizontalOffset { double get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets the horizontal offset of the scrolled content.
Docs.value: A that represents, in device independent pixels, the horizontal offset. This property has no default value.

remarks.format: ## Remarks Valid values are between zero and the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Primitives.IScrollInfo.ExtentWidth%2A> minus the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Primitives.IScrollInfo.ViewportWidth%2A>.

MemberSignature.Value: public System.Windows.Rect MakeVisible (System.Windows.Media.Visual visual, System.Windows.Rect rectangle);
.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance valuetype System.Windows.Rect MakeVisible(class System.Windows.Media.Visual visual, valuetype System.Windows.Rect rectangle) cil managed

Docs.param: A bounding rectangle that identifies the coordinate space to make visible.
Docs.summary: Forces content to scroll until the coordinate space of a object is visible.

remarks.format: ## Remarks In most cases, the returned rectangle is a transformed version of the input rectangle. In some cases, such as when the input rectangle cannot fit entirely within the viewport, the return value may be smaller.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property System::Windows::Controls::ScrollViewer ^ ScrollOwner { System::Windows::Controls::ScrollViewer ^ get(); void set(System::Windows::Controls::ScrollViewer ^ value); };

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a element that controls scrolling behavior.
Docs.value: A element that controls scrolling behavior. This property has no default value.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Classes that implement <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Primitives.IScrollInfo> must call <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ScrollViewer.InvalidateScrollInfo%2A> on this object when properties change.
Logical scrolling enables scrolling to the next element in the logical tree. Physical scrolling, in contrast, scrolls content by a defined measurable increment in a specified direction. If you require physical scrolling instead of logical scrolling, wrap the host <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Panel> element in a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ScrollViewer> and set the value of its <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ScrollViewer.CanContentScroll%2A> property to `false`.
## Examples The following example shows how to set the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Primitives.IScrollInfo.ScrollOwner%2A> property by using procedural code.
[!code-csharp[IScrollInfoMethods#4](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/IScrollInfoMethods/CSharp/Window1.xaml.cs#4)] [!code-vb[IScrollInfoMethods#4](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Wpf/IScrollInfoMethods/VisualBasic/Window1.xaml.vb#4)]

Docs.param: The degree to which content is vertically offset from the containing viewport.

public: property double VerticalOffset { double get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets the vertical offset of the scrolled content.
Docs.value: A that represents, in device independent pixels, the vertical offset of the scrolled content. Valid values are between zero and the minus the . This property has no default value.
